contextId.information: "In Christ Jesus" and similar expressions are metaphors that frequently occur in the New Testament letters. They express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who are faithful in Christ Jesus

contextId.information: Paul speaks of God's grace as if it were material wealth. AT: "greatness of God's grace" or "abundance of God's grace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: riches of his grace

contextId.information: Paul speaks of God's grace as if it were objects that could be increased in number. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He made this grace abound

contextId.information: The Ephesian Christians believed in Christ and are spoken of as being in union with him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: it was in him that you also have believed and were sealed

contextId.information: Wax was placed on a letter and stamped with a symbol representing the person who wrote the letter. Paul uses this custom as a picture to show how God has used the Holy Spirit to assure us that we belong to him. AT: "God has sealed you with the Holy Spirit that he promised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: were sealed with the promised Holy Spirit

contextId.information: Receiving what God has promised believers is spoken of as though one inherits property or wealth from a family member. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: inheritance

contextId.information: Receiving what God has promised believers, is spoken of as if one were inheriting property and wealth from a family member. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: inheritance

contextId.information: Here "head" refers to the leader or the one who is in charge. AT: "ruler over all things in the church" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the head over all things in the church

contextId.information: This shows how sinful people are unable to obey God in the same way a dead person is unable to respond physically. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you were dead in your trespasses and sins

contextId.information: This shows how a sinful person is unable to obey God until he is given new spiritual life just like a dead person is unable to respond physically unless he is raised from the dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: While we were dead in trespasses, he brought us to new life

contextId.information: This refers to people who were not born Jewish. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Gentiles in the flesh

contextId.information: Paul speaks to the Gentile believers as if they had been foreigners, kept out of the land of God's covenant and promise. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: strangers to the covenants of the promise

contextId.information: a single new people, the people of redeemed humanity (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: one new man

contextId.information: By dying on the cross Jesus eliminated the reason for Jews and Gentiles to be hostile toward each other. Neither are now required to live according to the law of Moses. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: With the cross he put to death the hostility

contextId.information: Paul is again speaking of the spiritual condition of Gentiles after they become believers as he would speak about foreigners becoming citizens of a different nation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you Gentiles ... God's household

contextId.information: Paul continues to speak of Christ's family as if it were a building. In the same way a builder fits stones together while building, so Christ is fitting us together. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the whole building fits together and grows as a temple

contextId.information: This describes how believers are being put together to become a place where God will permanently live through the power of the Holy Spirit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you also are being built together as a dwelling place for God in the Spirit

contextId.information: The church is often referred to as the body of Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: fellow members of the body

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the truth about Christ and the blessings he brings as if they were material wealth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: riches of Christ

contextId.information: Paul speaks of their faith as if it were a tree that has deep roots or a house built on a solid foundation. AT: "that you will be like a firmly rooted tree and a building built on stone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that you will be rooted and grounded in his love

contextId.information: Paul uses these expressions to describe the intensity with which Christ loves us. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the width, the length, the height, and the depth of Christ's love

contextId.information: Walking is a common way to express the idea of living one's life. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: walk worthily of the calling

contextId.information: The church is often referred to as the body of Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: one body

contextId.information: Paul is speaking of people who grow spiritually as if they were doing exercises to increase the strength of their physical bodies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: for the building up of the body of Christ

contextId.information: This speaks of a believer who has not become mature and follows wrong teaching as if that believer were a boat that the wind is blowing in different directions on the water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: tossed around ... carried away by every wind of teaching

contextId.information: Paul uses the human body to describe how Christ causes believers to work together in harmony as the head of a body causes the body parts to work together to grow healthy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: into him who is the head ... the whole body grows and builds itself up

contextId.information: Paul speaks of these people as if they were objects that they themselves were giving to other people, and he speaks of the way they want to satisfy their physical desires as if it were the person to whom they give themselves. AT: "All they want to do is satisfy their physical desires" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They have handed themselves over to sensuality

contextId.information: Paul is speaking of moral qualities as if they were pieces of clothing. AT: "You must change ... your behavior" or "You must put away ... the old man." See how you translated "old man" in [[:en:bible:notes:eph:04:20|4:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Put off your old man

contextId.information: A person who believes in Christ becomes a new person who lives differently just as a person looks totally different when he puts on new clothes, having "put off" the old way of living ([[:en:bible:notes:eph:04:20|4:22]]) and "put on the new." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that you may put on the new man

contextId.information: Receiving what God has promised believers is spoken of as if it were inheriting property and wealth from a family member. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: inheritance

contextId.information: Just as one cannot see in the dark, so people who love to sin lack spiritual understanding. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For you were once darkness

contextId.information: "live as people who understand what the Lord wants them to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: walk as children of light

contextId.information: Just as a healthy tree produces good fruit, a believer will do what is good, do the righteous things God wants him to do, and will speak true words. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the fruit of the light consists in all goodness, righteousness, and truth

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the useless, sinful things that unbelievers do as if they are evil deeds people do in the dark so no one will see them. AT: "Do not do useless, sinful things with unbelievers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Have no participation with the unfruitful works of the darkness

contextId.information: "bring them out into the light" or "uncover them" or "show and tell people how wrong these actions are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: expose them

contextId.information: "people can clearly see everything that comes into the light." While this is a metaphor for how the word of God shows people's actions to be good or bad, you should translate this literally. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: everything revealed is illuminated

contextId.information: Christ will enable an unbeliever to understand how evil his deeds are and how Christ will forgive him and give him new life, just as light shows what actually is there that darkness hid. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Christ will shine on you

contextId.information: The phrase "the body" is a metaphor for the church. This can be made explicit. AT: "Christ is the savior of the body of believers" or "Christ is the savior of all believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: He is the savior of the body

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) Paul is referring to God's making Christ's people clean by God's word and through water baptism in Christ or 2) Paul is saying God made us spiritually clean from our sins by the word of God as we make our bodies clean by washing with water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He cleansed her by the washing of water in the word

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the church as though it were a garment that is clean and in good condition. He uses the same idea in two ways to emphasize the church's purity. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: without stain or wrinkle

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "we are members of his body of believers" or 2) believers fit together to form the body of Christ just as the parts of the human body fit together to form a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: we are members of his body

contextId.information: Christians should use the protective resources God gives them in fighting the devil in the same way a soldier puts on armor to protect himself against his enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Therefore put on the whole armor of God

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the gift of righteousness covers a believer's heart just as a breastplate protects the chest of a soldier or 2) our living as God wants us, gives us a clear conscience that protects our hearts the way a breastplate protects a soldier's chest. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the breastplate of righteousness

contextId.information: The faith God gives a believer is to be used for protection when the devil attacks like a soldier uses a shield to protect from enemy attacks. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: In all circumstances pick up the shield of faith

contextId.information: Salvation given by God protects the believer's mind just as a helmet protects the head of a soldier. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: And take the helmet of salvation

contextId.information: The word of God, inspired by the Holy Spirit, is to be used to fight against and defend the believer from the devil just as a soldier uses his sword to fight and defend against enemy attacks. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God
